unnormalised: The year was 2010, and I, like many fresh graduates in India, had just landed my first job in Bangalore. My salary, a princely sum of Rs. 15,000 per month, felt like winning the lottery. It was more money than I'd ever handled, and my initial instinct was to splurge. But Amma, ever the pragmatist, quickly set me straight. "First, beta," she said over the phone from our home in Lucknow, "open a bank account. Put half your salary in it every month. And no withdrawing unless it's an emergency."
normalised: The year was two thousand and ten, and I, like many fresh graduates in India, had just landed my first job in Bangalore. My salary, a princely sum of rupee fifteen thousand per month, felt like winning the lottery. It was more money than I'd ever handled, and my initial instinct was to splurge. But Amma, ever the pragmatist, quickly set me straight. "First, beta," she said over the phone from our home in Lucknow, "open a bank account. Put half your salary in it every month. And no withdrawing unless it's an emergency."

unnormalised: So, I dutifully walked into the nearest branch of State Bank of India (SBI), armed with my offer letter and a copy of my PAN card. The process was surprisingly smooth. I filled out the forms, submitted the required documents, and within a week, I had my own savings account. The feeling of financial independence was intoxicating. I diligently deposited Rs. 7,500 every month, resisting the urge to buy the latest gadgets or splurge on weekend getaways. My first debit card felt like a magical key unlocking a world of possibilities, even if I mostly used it for withdrawing cash from ATMs.
normalised: So, I dutifully walked into the nearest branch of State Bank of India (S-B-I), armed with my offer letter and a copy of my P-A-N card. The process was surprisingly smooth. I filled out the forms, submitted the required documents, and within a week, I had my own savings account. The feeling of financial independence was intoxicating. I diligently deposited rupee seven thousand five hundred every month, resisting the urge to buy the latest gadgets or splurge on weekend getaways. My first debit card felt like a magical key unlocking a world of possibilities, even if I mostly used it for withdrawing cash from A-T-M-s.

unnormalised: One day, Amma called with an urgent request. "Your Dadi needs cataract surgery," she explained, her voice tight with worry. "The doctor says it will cost around ₹25,000. Can you help?" Without hesitation, I logged into my internet banking account, a relatively new and exciting technology at the time. Transferring the funds was surprisingly simple – a few clicks, an OTP authentication, and the money was on its way. I remember the relief washing over me, knowing that I could contribute to my grandmother's well-being. It was a far cry from the days when sending money home meant queuing up at a post office and filling out money order forms.

unnormalised: A few years later, I decided to invest in a small piece of land back in Lucknow. The initial down payment was Rs. 2 lakh. I remember the daunting task of accumulating that sum. It meant carefully budgeting my expenses, cutting back on eating out, and foregoing unnecessary purchases. I even started a small side hustle, tutoring students online for Rs. 500 per hour. Slowly but surely, the savings grew. When the time came to make the payment, I remember the bank manager congratulating me on my prudent financial planning.

unnormalised: The advent of UPI (Unified Payments Interface) revolutionized the way I handled smaller transactions. No more fumbling for change at the local chai stall, where a glass cost just Rs. 10. No more haggling with auto-rickshaw drivers over a fare of ₹80. A simple scan of a QR code and the payment was done. It was incredibly convenient, especially during the demonetization period when cash was scarce.

unnormalised: Now, years later, my financial life is significantly more complex. I manage multiple accounts, investments in stocks, mutual funds, and even cryptocurrency. I track my expenses using sophisticated apps and monitor my credit score religiously. But I will never forget those early lessons learned from Amma, those first experiences with banking and cash transactions that laid the foundation for my financial journey. From that first salary of Rs. 15,000 to the lakhs I manage today, the core principles of saving, budgeting, and investing remain the same.

unnormalised: And I still visit that same SBI branch occasionally, a nostalgic reminder of where it all began. The faces have changed, the technology has evolved, but the fundamental purpose remains: to safeguard our hard-earned money and help us achieve our financial goals. Whether it's transferring ₹25,000 for Dadi's surgery or accumulating Rs. 2 lakh for a down payment on land, the power of banking and cash transactions, in all their evolving forms, continues to shape our lives.
